Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Investigating the Subsistence Transition in Post-Lapita Fiji (2500-1500 years BP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With National Science Foundation support, Drs. Julie Field, Chris Roos, and John Dudgeon will use archaeological, geoarchaeological, and paleoecological analyses to explore the transition from marine foraging to sedentary farming in the centuries following the colonization of the Fiji Islands.

This research will determine how and when food production developed in Fijian prehistory, and examine how this transition relates to evident changes in diet, settlement, material culture, demography, and island ecology. This topic is particularly relevant to current research questions in Oceania, in particular the decline of the signature elements of the founding society, the Lapita, and the emergence of the core components of the Oceanic societies of New Caledonia, Fiji, Tonga, and Samoa. By the contact period these island groups had large populations, vast agricultural systems, and ranked societies, but the relative importance of food production to this process is not well understood and has received little direct study.

The team will focus on the Sigatoka Valley, located on the island of Viti Levu, and will examine the range of variables used to forage or produce food. The researchers will employ a high-resolution retrodictive GIS-based model. This model will provide the foundation for geoarchaeological investigations within several watersheds to determine the frequency of natural and human-induced fire, and build a picture of landscape change from forest canopy to open farmland. Large areal excavations will be conducted with the goal of retrieving evidence of foraging and food production by Fiji's earliest inhabitants. Radiocarbon dating of features and artifacts related to food processing and consumption will be used to generate a chronology for agricultural development in Fiji. The project will also conduct isotopic analyses on recovered bone in order to examine human diet, the relative increasing importance of cultivated foods.

Research in Fiji will build upon a history of collaboration between US archaeologists and the Fiji Museum that began in 1947. Fieldwork and subsequent laboratory analyses will provide training and research opportunities for students in Fiji and the United States, and will be connected to a series of educational programs for Fijian adults and schoolchildren that emphasizes cultural resource management and the natural sciences. Reports and data generated from this project will be shared with local communities via the Fiji Museum, and also published internationally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our goal was to outline the history of fire in Fiji's past, and to connect that history to subsequent farming activities by human colonizers. We also sought to create an isotopic survey of foods in Fiji that could have been a part of the diet of the earliest farmers, to match to any future bioarchaeological or geoarchaeological research in diet and agricultural practices. Our archaeological investigations sought to detect farming on the ground, and determine its antiquity and connection to broad patterns of landscape change caused by people in their efforts to create sustainable agricultural practices. We also sought to identify humans as farmers and determine their biological origins and connections to one another.

We determined the history of natural fire in Fiji extends into antiquity and prior to colonization, but that human arrival in Fiji had a dramatic effect on the vegetation of the island, reducing forests to grasslands and opening up former dense canopies to sunlight. Farming appeared early in the interior of Viti Levu Fiij ca. 2500 years BP, which is significant in that it documents that human use of the landscape for farming stretches back to the earliest period following colonization. We also determined that there is an early signature for farming in the form of introduced banana (Musa spp.) plant skeletons (phytoliths), which came as a crop to Fiji, possibly with the first human arrival in the Sigatoka river valley. We also outlined a food web for Fiji that includes a number of endemic and introduced foods, which will have utility in the future in determining human dietary trends in antiquity.

We presented our research at national, international, and local venues, and also published a single article in the Journal of Ethnobiolgy. Several other articles are in preparation and will be submitted to other journals in the future. Additionally, two student theses, K. Riordan, Ohio State University (2018) and R. Hazard, Idaho State University (2017) were produced from this project.

Printed reports of our research results have been produced in a format appropriate for the general public and have been hand-carried to Fiji and given to communities that participated in the project. The reports have also been filed with local land owners, the provincial offices of the region, the Ministry of Education, and the Fiji Museum. Several public lectures were also given, and papers and publications uploaded to websites such as Academia.edu and Research Gate and made available to the public. Publications are also accessible in academic journals.
